_chemical.ChemicalName: Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Valero Refining - Texas L.P. (Valero)
Texas City Refinery
EPA ID# 1000 0010 7886
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

1  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Valero is committed to operating and maintaining all of the refining processes in a safe and responsible 
manner.  Valero uses a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response 
planning programs to help ensure the safety of employees and the public as well as protection of the 
environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities 
that Valero has designed and implemented, including:

* A description of the facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation
* An overview of accidental release prevention programs
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
* An overview of emergency response program
* An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases 
        from occurring and adversely affecting employees, the public, and the environment
* The certifications that EPA's RMP rule requires the regulated facility to provide
* The detailed information (called data elements) about Valero's Risk Management Program

2  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Valero is a petroleum refinery that produces gasoline, diesel, petroleum coke, and streams for use as 
chemical feedstock, using a variety of processing operations.  In refining processes, Valero utilizes 
flammable and toxic chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite 
consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release.  Regulated flammable chemicals at the 
facility include butane, isobutane, isopentane, propane, propylene, hydrogen, and other miscellaneous 
flammable mixtures.  In addition, the facility contains hydrogen fluoride and hydrogen sulfide that are 
regulated toxic substances

.  The refinery includes a total of twenty-two covered processes for purposes of 
this Risk Management Plan.  Several other process units may contain regulated substances; however, 
these do not meet the definition of a flammable mixture, or are below the threshold quantity.

The current RMP submittal is an update for process changes that have occurred at the refinery recently.  
Process changes include the following:

* Conversion of the Utilities Plant and process cooling towers from Chlorine to Bleach
* Conversion of the MTBE unit to Indirect Alkylation (InAlk)

These process changes have resulted in the removal of the Utilities Plant and MTBE and the addition of 
the InAlk process unit for this submittal.  Several process units have been separated to meet the 
refinery's Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  In addition, this submittal is to include six 
process units that now have regulated substances above threshold as a result of increased refinery 
production.  These new process units include the following:

* #2 Amine
* #3 Sulfur Recovery Unit (SRU)
* Middle Distillate Hydrotreater (MDHT)
* Gas Oil Hydrotreater (GOHT)
* Resid SRU, #1 & #2 TGU
* Resid Amine, Resid SWS

Valero's accidental release prevention programs and contingency planning efforts help effectively 
manage the hazards that are posed to employees, the public, and the environment by Valero's use of 
these substances.

3  OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS SCENARIOS

EPA's RMP rule requires that Valero conduct studies to identify worst-case release scenarios and 
alternative release scenarios for the facility.  A summary of those scenarios, including information about 
the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario 
is provided in the appropriate section of this Risk Management Plan.

Valero is using this information to help ensure that the emergency response plan and the community 
emergency response plan address all reasonable contingen

cy cases.

4  GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Valero maintains a number of programs to help prevent accidental releases and ensure safe operation.  
The accident prevention programs in place include:

OSHA PSM elements, including employee participation programs, process safety information, process 
hazard analyses, operating procedures and training, mechanical integrity programs with training, 
contractor programs, incident investigation, management of change, pre-startup safety reviews, 
compliance audits, and hot work and safe work programs.  Additionally, Valero has implemented various 
safety programs addressing safe personnel protective clothing and equipment, hearing protection, safe 
entry and exit controls, impact protection and secondary containment controls, and a detailed analysis 
and adherence to generally accepted industry codes and standards.  Valero has additionally adopted the 
Texas City area contractors training program to assure that only qualified contractor personnel may enter 
the facility.  Valero has made every effort to assure compliance with OSHA PSM, dating back to 1992.  
Program improvements have been implemented following PSM audits in 1995, 1998, and 2006.  
Accordingly, the dates provided in Section 7. Prevention Program Level 3 represents the latest updates to 
the program elements.

In March of 2002, Valero's Texas City refinery was recognized as a "Star Site" in OSHA's Voluntary 
Protection Program (VPP). Star Site designation is OSHA's highest honor to recognize the nation's most 
effective industrial safety and health programs. To date, only 15% of U.S. refineries have earned this 
distinction. One of the key success indicators that earned the Valero Texas City refinery Star Site 
designation is the plant's continually declining injury rates. For the last three years, the refinery's 
recordable employee injury rate has been well below the industry average. The refinery's cont

ractor 
recordable injury rate has also been better than industry standards and has seen a 50 percent reduction 
in the last two years.

As part of the refinery's prevention efforts, Valero has implemented the following chemical-specific 
prevention steps:

For toxic chemicals, hydrogen fluoride and hydrogen sulfide, Valero has reviewed and adopted industry 
guidelines and manufacturer's recommendations regarding safe storage and handling.  This includes 
personnel training as well as robust equipment designs.  For flammables, Valero has adopted several 
API, NFPA, insurance company, ASME, ANSI, and other codes and standards.
                                                                                                     
These individual elements of Valero's prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical 
releases.  Valero and its employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set 
for the way Valero does business, and Valero has specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that 
Valero is meeting its own high standards for accident prevention.

5  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Valero keeps records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at the facility.  There have 
been no releases of a threshold amount stated by the RMP rule at the Valero Texas City Refinery in the 
past five years.  For the incidents that do not meet EPA's definition, Valero has conducted formal incident 
investigations to identify and correct the identified causes of the events.

6  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

Valero maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and 
local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Valero's program provides the essential 
planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency 
situations.  Furthermore, Valero coordinates its plan with the community emergency response plan 
throug

h Industries Mutual Aid Society and the Texas City Fire Department. 

7  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Valero is continuously investigating and reviewing technology and / or applications that could possibly 
enhance its safety efforts.

8  CERTIFICATIONS

Within the past five years, the processes had no accidental release that caused offsite impacts provided 
in the RMP rule (40 CFR 68.10(b)(1)).  No additional measures are necessary to prevent offsite impacts 
from accidental releases.  In the event of fire, explosion, or a release of a regulated substance from the 
processes, entry within the distance to the specified endpoints may pose a danger to public emergency 
responders.  Therefore, public emergency responders should not enter this area except as arranged with 
the emergency contact indicated in the RMP.  The undersigned certifies that, to the best of my 
knowledge, information, and belief, formed after reasonable inquiry, the information submitted is true 
accurate, and complete.


Signature:     Les G. Rucker
Title:             Director, Health, Safety, & Environmental
Date:            June 06, 2008
